isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: TRW/ROSS-TAS 40, 55, 65 AND 85 - GLOSSARY

deflist.def: Fluid with air bubbles
Gears are mounted in such a way that trapped air can be forced out of the system "automatically" without loosening bleed screw
In-out movement along an axis (imaginary straight line on which an object moves)
Dents
Date the steering gear was built (Julian date)
Change in color
Fluid leaking out of the system or steering gear
Hub contacts axle stop
Steering gear has manual steering mechanism, hydraulic control valve, and hydraulic power cylinder all within gear housing
The application of torques and forces to steering gear components during accidents or other similar events which exceed the hydraulic capacity of the steering gear
Fluid leaking inside the gear
Free play
Gears are mounted in such a way that an air pocket could form in one end of steering gear. The bleed screw is positioned so trapped air can be forced out when loosened.
Occupational Safety and Health Administration
Unloading valves, reduce pressure in full turns
Limits maximum supply pressure
Line that connects steering gear to reservoir to recirculate hydraulic fluid
Controls flow in internal cavities
Scratch
Shake or jar
Flaking or chipping
An assembled unit that fits into a larger unit
Line that connects pump to steering gear
Output shaft serrations damaged by impact overload. Serrations can be twisted at the area between the large diameter of the shaft and the end of the serrations.
